title: CBA moves first on Hayne adviser fees call
text:
"Trustees should consider all necessary steps to make sure that members are clearly aware of fees being deducted from their account," wrote APRA deputy chairwoman Helen Rowell and ASIC commissioner Danielle Press.

"Best practice would be to obtain effective consumer authorisation to charge the fees on a regular basis."

Despite the guidance from regulators, legislation requiring trustees to seek additional confirmation from members of ongoing advice fees deducted from their account has not yet been introduced to the Federal Parliament.

Recommendation 2.1 of the Hayne inquiry called for the law to be amended so that ongoing fees be "renewed annually by the client", and that product providers obtain “express written authority” to deduct any payments from their accounts.

A consultation is currently underway and legislation acting on this recommendation is due to be introduced by 30 June, 2020, according to Treasury's royal commission implementation roadmap.

Vast majority of adviser fees

CBA is understood to be the first of the major banks to take this proactive stance to ongoing adviser service fees.

Sources within the financial advice community expressed dismay that CBA had changed its policy regarding ongoing adviser fees prior to Treasury's consultation process or the release of draft legislation.

Advertisement

The vast majority of service fees in the industry are believed to be administered by trustees and financial product manufacturers as a deduction from investor accounts, with fees for service paid directly from clients to financial advisers still a minority.

CFS has $50 billion in funds under management as at May 2019 and financial adviser distribution is a major strategic focus for the bank, both within CBA and with independent advisory groups.

A CFS spokesperson confirmed the change in policy to The Australian Financial Review, again pointing to APRA and ASIC guidance as a motivator for the decision.

"We are working closely with advisers to ensure they have early awareness and we will support them with contacting their clients to reconfirm their advice service fees," the spokesperson said.

Ending commissions

The decision to contact members to seek consent for ongoing adviser fee deductions comes as CFS and the other big bank-owned wealth managers are in varying stages of ending commission payments to financial advisers.

Legislation compelling fund managers and financial product providers to cease payment of any conflicted payments to financial advisers by January 1, 2021 was passed by the Federal Parliament on 14 October, acting on Recommendation 2.4 of the royal commission.

All four of the big banks and AMP have told the Financial Review they will cease the payment of commissions by January 1, 2021.

But consumer advocacy group Choice is concerned that the process of ending commission payments will provide an opportunity for financial services companies to simply cut out intermediary advisers and enrich themselves.
description: Commonwealth Bank's wealth arm has warned financial advisers it will be writing to clients and asking them to re-confirm fee payments.
